AP Capstone is a diploma program from the College Board. It’s based on two yearlong AP courses: AP Seminar and AP Research. Rather than teaching subject-specific content, these courses develop students’ skills in research, analysis, evidence-based arguments, collaboration, writing, and presenting. Students who complete the two-year program can earn one of two different AP Capstone awards, which are valued by colleges across the United States…

Springboro Panther Football is back! Tomorrow, August 28 at 7:00pm Springboro will play host to Northmont at CareFlight Field at Watkins Stadium.

If you are attending the game, visit www.boropanthers.com for seating guidelines at CareFlight Field at Watkins Stadium.

If you are unable to attend in-person, you can still watch games this season! The Springboro Athletic Department has agreed to partner with Turnkey Digital Solutions (TKDS) to stream Panther games throughout the 2020-2021 season! TKDS will film, broadcast, and announce live games this Fall including all home contests for Varsity Football, Volleyball, and Soccer.

TKDS is a subscription based service with nearly 90% of all subscription revenue coming back to the Springboro Athletic Department. This will be a great option this year with facility restrictions, and is always a great way for out-of-town family and friends to watch their favorite Panther player.

Register for Springboro Sports Network Here -
https://videos.tkdssports.com/watch-springboro-sports-network/

Samantha Pilley, a 6th grade student at Springboro Intermediate (SI), came up with an idea to make “Hope Bracelets” to give to residents in local nursing homes for Mother’s Day.

During Samantha's free time in quarantine, she weaved together handmade bracelets out of colorful string. Samantha also had help making the bracelets from her friend, Brianna Spencer, who lives in Charleston, WV.

It took a little over two (2) hours to complete a single bracelet. Both Samantha and Spencer made a total of fifty-seven (57) colorful bracelets with various designs on them, including hearts.

Samantha’s hope was to share positive joy inside the nursing homes, as well as to let the residents know they are being thought of, especially during this difficult time when many nursing home residents can’t be with family.

Each bracelet was sent with a note from Samantha, which read: "My name is Samantha. I'm a 6th grade student at Springboro Intermediate. I made bracelets for you all to enjoy during this pandemic. I hope you enjoy them and they brighten up your day."

Andy Goldsworthy is a British sculptor, photographer, and environmentalist who is internationally known for using materials found in nature for site specific works of art.

For a recent lesson plan, "Ode to Goldsworthy," Mrs. Sav's Springboro High School (SHS) Sculpture students researched Goldsworthy's work, created sketches, and then went outdoors to complete their own sculptures with objects found in nature.

Students focused on balance, composition, pattern, light source, camera angles, and being innovative with their materials. The students took to the fresh air and assembled unique works of art in creeks, their backyards, along hiking paths, and even incorporated some sculptures within trees.

As residents in nursing homes around the country are dealing with the effects of being quarantined, Springboro Intermediate (SI) students in Mr. Bettinger's class were given an optional assignment that would benefit a large number of people going through a difficult time.

The students wrote letters to nursing home residents at Grande Lake Healthcare Center in St. Marys, OH. The students wrote about themselves and the things they like to do in their free time, while also asking the residents about their interests. Students would then end the letter with a joke or riddle.

Pictured here is a Grande Lake Healthcare Center staff member sharing one of the letters with Helen, a resident, in addition to some of the letters written by students. All the residents and staff members from Grande Lake enjoyed these very much!

Plans are already in the works to reach out to nursing homes around the Springboro area, in order to continue to this uplifting project.

Congratulations to Springboro High School (SHS) Junior Hannah Hill on being a State Swimming Champion!

The Springboro girls swimmers competed in the Finals of the Ohio High School Athletic Association’s (OHSAA) State Swim Meet in Canton, Ohio. The girls pulled off a phenomenal performance, finishing 6th overall as a team while only having a total of 4 girls swimming.

Junior Hannah Hill became the 3rd Swimming State Champion in Springboro history – and she did it twice – winning the 50 Yard Freestyle and adding the 100 Yard Freestyle title later in the meet.

Senior Maggie Clough was the State Runner Up in the 100 Yard Backstroke and added an 8th place finish in the 100 Yard Butterfly. Junior Abby Susec won the consolation final in the 100 Yard Backstroke, finishing 9th overall in the State in the event. In addition, Senior Molly Arneson teamed with Hill, Clough, and Susec to finish 6th in the 200 Yard Medley Relay and 4th in the 400 Yard Freestyle Relay.

SHS Air Force Junior ROTC recently held their annual Dining-Out ceremony at the Mandalay Banquet & Event Center. The formal dinner is an annual tradition in which Air Force units come together to honor military customs and achievements.

Freshman and sophomore cadets performed a Color Guard and presented the Colors for the National Anthem. Sophomore cadets, with military sabres, performed a sabre team formation for the entrance to the distinguished guests.

A final highlight was a ceremonial tribute to those service members who are prisoners of war (POW) or are still missing in action (MIA). The POW/MIA ceremony was performed by several junior cadets, which involved a tribute around a table set for one.

The evening culminated with Representative George Lang, Ohio House District 52, addressing the crowd as the keynote speaker. Over 375 cadets, parents, and administrators attended the event.

Representing SHS this year will be Belle DeRosa and Eliza Gilbert. Belle and Eliza competed in an essay competition focused on what leadership means to them.

The HOBY is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to inspire a global community of youth to a life dedicated to leadership, service and innovation.

This year's 2020 Southwest Ohio Conference is being held on Antioch College's campus. Congratulations to Belle and Eliza!

Springboro High School's Junior ROTC Leadership & Academic Bowl Team has advanced to Level II testing in the JROTC national competition. The SHS JROTC team completed Level I testing prior to winter break. 490 JROTC teams from across the nation competed in Level I. Of those, 280 teams advanced to Level II. The team will do Level II testing in February. After that, the top sixteen (16) teams in Level II testing will advance to the National Championships in Washington DC, which will be held June 2020.

The JROTC Leadership & Academic Bowl testing is based on SAT/ACT material such as science, math, grammar, and reading comprehension. The test also includes JROTC curriculum, as well as current events. The SHS team took the Level I test scoring a 93% overall.

Pictured (L to R): Andrew Forney, Eli Barker, Adin Stoller, Kevin Cooper, Linus Kennedy, and Abigail Galbraith

Springboro Schools joined more than 700 school districts throughout Ohio to celebrate January as School Board Recognition Month. At the January 7th Board of Education meeting, Ms. Konkle, Technology/STEM Teacher at Dennis Elementary, presented to the Board of Education on STEM technology. Ms. Konkle's students from Dennis worked with board members and administration on a Valentine's Day activity with paper circuits.

“Our school board members are citizen-servants who shoulder critical responsibilities and often make difficult choices for our district, said Interim Superintendent Carrie Hester. “Their focus is always on the future success of the students in our district. Celebrating School Board Recognition Month is one way to say thanks for all they do.”

Serving as a link between the community and classroom, school board members are elected to establish the policies that provide the framework for public schools.
